From Lifelong "Maker" to Design Innovator

As a lifelong "maker" fascinated by the intersection of science, technology and artistic expression, my path to design was an organic evolution.

Syracuse University

My formal training was a 5-year industrial design program at Syracuse University, where an influential professor named Rolf Faste (who later taught the "design thinking" process at Stanford) instilled a human-centered, iterative approach that became the bedrock of my philosophy.

Industrial Design

My early career included industrial design roles creating hunting gear, sporting goods and word processors.

UX Design

It was at the innovative tech giant Xerox where my passion for user-experince design truly took shape. Xerox's drive for company coherence in design taught me about design systems. Their vision of design as a key business differentiator resonated deeply and elevated the influence of my work.

Design for Human Empowerment

Whether crafting physical products or pioneering user experiences in an emerging digital era, my design process remained rooted in thoughtful observation, research and an innate drive to solve real human needs through innovative yet simple solutions. This mindset, honed over decades, became the ethos behind my powerful "Design for Human Empowerment" approach.

With over 25 years of experience in UX design, I've learned that true empowerment through design requires an unwavering focus on user needs.

Reframing Through Observation

Great design solves the right problems. That's why open dialogue and careful observation of end-users is critical. It allows us to reframe challenges from their perspective to ensure we aren't making flawed assumptions. Only by deeply understanding their real needs can we innovate solutions that truly empower.

Exploring Wide, Converging Narrow

My iterative process cycles between divergent exploration and convergent refinement. I cast a wide net through research and "how might we" ideation to uncover unexpected possibilities. Then I narrow focus, filtering ideas pragmatically until the strongest, most innovative yet simple solutions align with core human needs.

Form Suggests Function

Every line, color, label and icon choice serves to elegantly communicate purpose in a way that feels natural and empowering. Minimalism strips away visual clutter to provide a calm, focused environment where creativity thrives.

Innovative Simplicity

Innovation means using new ideas and technology to solve real problems with refreshing simplicity. My passion combines cutting-edge thinking with deep respect for the human experience to create tools that make daily lives more effortless and enriching.
